conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves to the back right.
The initial setup shows a light source positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly downward. Shadows A, B, C, and D are relatively short and close to the objects.
Shadow A corresponds to the circular object (cake-like).
Shadow B corresponds to the vertical stick.
Shadow C corresponds to the cylindrical object (medical roll).
Shadow D corresponds to the ring.
When the light source moves to the back right, the direction of the shadows changes, pointing toward the front left.
The size of the shadows will change depending on the relative height and angle of the light source, generally elongating as the light source moves further away or at a lower angle.
Shadow A will shift to the front left of the circular object and elongate slightly due to the angled light source.
Shadow B will shift to the front left of the stick and elongate significantly because the stick is tall and the light source is at a lower angle.
Shadow C will shift to the front left of the cylinder and elongate slightly, as the cylinder is relatively short compared to the stick.
Shadow D will shift to the front left of the ring and elongate slightly, with less pronounced size change compared to taller objects.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shift to the front left of their respective objects when the light source moves to the back right.
Shadow B (vertical stick) will elongate the most due to its height, while shadows A, C, and D will elongate slightly, with C elongating more than A and D.
